---
title: "Hands-on Exercise 1"
author: "Jeffery Lau"
date: 08-17-2024
date-modified: "last-modified"
description: |
  In this exercise we get our first hands-on with geoprocessing and basic plotting with R
categories:
  - Hands-on
format:
  html:
    toc: true
execute: 
  eval: true
  echo: true
  warning: false
  freeze: true
---


# 1. Getting Started

The following code chunk uses p_load() to install and load the sf and tidyverse packages.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(sf, tidyverse)
```
:::


# 2. Importing data

The following code chunk will import the Master Plan and Cycling Path data in ESRI shapefile format and Preschool data in kml file format into R.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz = st_read(dsn="data/geospatial",
                layer="MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `/Users/jeffery/S0methingSimple/IS415-GAA/hands-on_ex/ex01/data/geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
cyclingpath = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                         layer = "CyclingPathGazette")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `/Users/jeffery/S0methingSimple/IS415-GAA/hands-on_ex/ex01/data/geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 3138 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11854.32 ymin: 28347.98 xmax: 42644.17 ymax: 48948.15
Projected CRS: SVY21
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool = st_read("data/geospatial/PreSchoolsLocation.kml")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source 
  `/Users/jeffery/S0methingSimple/IS415-GAA/hands-on_ex/ex01/data/geospatial/PreSchoolsLocation.kml' 
  using driver `KML'
Simple feature collection with 2290 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```


:::
:::


# 3. Working with Simple Feature Data Frame

This section document ways to retrieve information from and work with data frames

1.  Using `st_geometry()` function we can view basic information of the data frame


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Geometry set for 323 features 
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
First 5 geometries:
```


:::
:::


2.  Using `glimpse()` we can view the associated attributes of the data frame


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

Columns: 16
```

:::
:::


3.  Using `head()` we can retrieve the complete information of the feature object


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
head(mpsz, n=5)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}


:::
:::


# 4. Plotting the Geospatial Data

To perform a simple plot use `plot()`, in this case the default plot is a multi-plot of all attributes.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


To plot just the geometry, use `st_geometry()` in the `plot()` function.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(mpsz))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


To view a specific attribute use the following


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz["PLN_AREA_N"])
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


# 5. Map Projection

In the event when the coordinate system of the source data is either missing or wrongly assigned we will have to update it.

## 5.1 Assign EPSG Code

In the case of `mpsz` it is projected in `SVY 21` with EPSG code 3414, using `st_crs()` we can see that the data is projected with EPSG code 9001 instead.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_crs(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: SVY21 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21[WGS84]",
        DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
            ID["EPSG",6326]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]]],
    CONVERSION["unnamed",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["(E)",east,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]],
        AXIS["(N)",north,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]]]
```


:::
:::


In order to update EPSG code to 3414 we can set the crs using the `st_set_crs()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
 mpsz3414 <- st_set_crs(mpsz, 3414)
```
:::


The crs for the mpsz data should now be assigned appropriately


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_crs(mpsz3414)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: EPSG:3414 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21 / Singapore TM",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21",
        DATUM["SVY21",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433]],
        ID["EPSG",4757]],
    CONVERSION["Singapore Transverse Mercator",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["northing (N)",north,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
        AXIS["easting (E)",east,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
    USAGE[
        SCOPE["Cadastre, engineering survey, topographic mapping."],
        AREA["Singapore - onshore and offshore."],
        BBOX[1.13,103.59,1.47,104.07]],
    ID["EPSG",3414]]
```


:::
:::


## 5.2 Re-Project CRS

In the case of the Preschool data, it is initially projected in `WGS 84`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(preschool)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Geometry set for 2290 features 
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
First 5 geometries:
```


:::
:::


In order to reproject the CRS from `WGS 84` to `SVY 21` we have to use `st_transform()` function instead


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool3414 <- st_transform(preschool, 
                              crs = 3414)
```
:::


The crs for the preschool data should now be assigned appropriately as well


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(preschool3414)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Geometry set for 2290 features 
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 11810.03 ymin: 25596.33 xmax: 45404.24 ymax: 49300.88
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
First 5 geometries:
```


:::
:::


# 6. Working with Aspatial Data

## 6.1 Importing data

AirBnb data is a listing and should be loaded with `read_csv()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings <- read_csv("data/aspatial/listings.csv")
```
:::


Using `list()` we can view the listings


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list(listings)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[[1]]
# A tibble: 3,540 × 18
       id name      host_id host_name neighbourhood_group neighbourhood latitude
    <dbl> <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     <chr>               <chr>            <dbl>
 1  71609 Ensuite …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 2  71896 B&B  Roo…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 3  71903 Room 2-n…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 4 275343 10min wa… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 5 275344 15 mins … 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 6 289234 Booking …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.34
 7 294281 5 mins w… 1521514 Elizabeth Central Region      Newton            1.31
 8 324945 Comforta… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 9 330095 Relaxing… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
10 344803 Budget s…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
# ℹ 3,530 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: longitude <dbl>, room_type <chr>, price <dbl>,
#   minimum_nights <dbl>, number_of_reviews <dbl>, last_review <date>,
#   reviews_per_month <dbl>, calculated_host_listings_count <dbl>,
#   availability_365 <dbl>, number_of_reviews_ltm <dbl>, license <chr>
```


:::
:::


We assume the data uses the `wgs84` Geographic Coordinate System

## 6.2 Aspatial data to `sf` Data Frame

The aspatial data will first be converted into an sf data frame and re-projected into the `SVY 21` crs.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings_sf <- st_as_sf(listings, 
                       coords = c("longitude", "latitude"),
                       crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)
```
:::


The created data frame shows that geometry has been added while longitude and latitude have been dropped


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(listings_sf)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Rows: 3,540
Columns: 17
$ id                             <dbl> 71609, 71896, 71903, 275343, 275344, 28…
$ name                           <chr> "Ensuite Room (Room 1 & 2) near EXPO", …
$ host_id                        <dbl> 367042, 367042, 367042, 1439258, 143925…
$ host_name                      <chr> "Belinda", "Belinda", "Belinda", "Kay",…
$ neighbourhood_group            <chr> "East Region", "East Region", "East Reg…
$ neighbourhood                  <chr> "Tampines", "Tampines", "Tampines", "Bu…
$ room_type                      <chr> "Private room", "Private room", "Privat…
$ price                          <dbl> NA, 80, 80, 50, 50, NA, 85, 65, 45, 54,…
$ minimum_nights                 <dbl> 92, 92, 92, 180, 180, 92, 92, 180, 180,…
$ number_of_reviews              <dbl> 19, 24, 46, 20, 16, 12, 131, 17, 5, 60,…
$ last_review                    <date> 2020-01-17, 2019-10-13, 2020-01-09, 20…
$ reviews_per_month              <dbl> 0.12, 0.15, 0.29, 0.15, 0.11, 0.08, 0.8…
$ calculated_host_listings_count <dbl> 6, 6, 6, 49, 49, 6, 7, 49, 49, 6, 7, 7,…
$ availability_365               <dbl> 89, 148, 90, 62, 0, 88, 365, 0, 0, 365,…
$ number_of_reviews_ltm          <dbl> 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0, …
$ license                        <chr> NA, NA, NA, "S0399", "S0399", NA, NA, "…
$ geometry                       <POINT [m]> POINT (41972.5 36390.05), POINT (…
```


:::
:::


# 7. Geoprocessing `sf` Data Frame

## 7.1 Buffering

Scenario: The authority is planning to upgrade the exiting cycling path. To do so, they need to acquire 5 metres of reserved land on the both sides of the current cycling path. You are tasked to determine the extend of the land need to be acquired and their total area.

Using the `st_buffer()` we can first compute the 5-meter buffer around paths of the cycling data


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling <- st_buffer(cyclingpath,
                              dist=5, nQuadSegs = 30)
```
:::


Then the area is calculated


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling$AREA <- st_area(buffer_cycling)
```
:::


Finally the `sum()` is used to derive the total land involved


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(buffer_cycling$AREA)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
2218855 [m^2]
```


:::
:::


## 7.2 Point-in-polygon count

Scenario: A pre-school service group want to find out the numbers of pre-schools in each Planning Subzone.

Using `st_intersects()` we could locate the preschool in each planning subzone from the master plan, and using the `length()` we can calculate the number of school in their respective subzone.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414$`PreSch Count`<- lengths(st_intersects(mpsz3414, preschool3414))
```
:::


Use `summary()` to get the summarised statistics of the `PreSch Count` field


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(mpsz3414$`PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   0.00    0.00    4.00    7.09   10.00   72.00 
```


:::
:::


Then, to list the planning subzone with the most number of pre-schools we could use `top_n()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
top_n(mpsz3414, 1, `PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 16 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 39655.33 ymin: 35966 xmax: 42940.57 ymax: 38622.37
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
  OBJECTID SUBZONE_NO     SUBZONE_N SUBZONE_C CA_IND PLN_AREA_N PLN_AREA_C
1      189          2 TAMPINES EAST    TMSZ02      N   TAMPINES         TM
     REGION_N REGION_C          INC_CRC FMEL_UPD_D   X_ADDR   Y_ADDR SHAPE_Leng
1 EAST REGION       ER 21658EAAF84F4D8D 2014-12-05 41122.55 37392.39   10180.62
  SHAPE_Area                       geometry PreSch Count
1    4339824 MULTIPOLYGON (((42196.76 38...           72
```


:::
:::


Next, using the `st_aera()` we can calculate the area of preschool by subzone


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414$Area <- mpsz3414 %>%
  st_area()
```
:::


Next, using `mutate()` to compute the density by dividing the `PreSch Count` over the calculated `Area` field


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414 <- mpsz3414 %>%
  mutate(`PreSch Density` = `PreSch Count`/Area * 1000000)
```
:::


# 8. Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

Using `hist()` we can view the distribution of `PreSch Density`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mpsz3414$`PreSch Density`)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


This can further customized using `ggplot2` such as the colors, no. of bins, title etc.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=mpsz3414, 
       aes(x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color="azure4", 
                 fill="aquamarine") +
  labs(title = "Are pre-school even distributed in Singapore?",
       subtitle= "There are many planning sub-zones with a single pre-school, on the other hand, \nthere are two planning sub-zones with at least 20 pre-schools",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Frequency")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


Using `ggplot2` it can also be plotted as a scatterplot; which shows the relationship between **Pre-school Density and Pre-school Count.**


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data=mpsz3414, 
       aes(y = `PreSch Count`, 
           x= as.numeric(`PreSch Density`)))+
  geom_point(color="cadetblue", 
             fill="black") +
  xlim(0, 40) +
  ylim(0, 40) +
  labs(title = "",
      x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
      y = "Pre-school count")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](ho_ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
